title: 114_s1435
content: The Act may be cited as the "Organ Donation Awareness and Promotion Act of 2015". Congress finds that there is a significant need for organ donation, with over 123,400 individuals on the waiting list in May 2015. In 2014, 14,413 individuals became organ donors, leading to 29,531 transplants, while 6,198 individuals died while waiting for a transplant. On average, 21 people die every day while waiting for an organ donation. Despite over 100,000,000 registered organ and tissue donors in the US, the demand still exceeds the supply. Many people are unaware of their donation options or have not communicated their wishes to their families. Organ and tissue donation can provide hope to those on the waiting list by allowing up to eight individuals to receive life-saving organs from a single deceased donor. Living donors can also save lives by donating a kidney, lung, or liver. The Sense of Congress is stated in Section 3. The Sense of Congress in Section 3 emphasizes the importance of public education on organ donation, honoring individuals who pledge to donate, and recognizing the generosity of deceased organ donors and their families. The Sense of Congress in Section 3 highlights the significance of public education on organ donation, honoring individuals who pledge to donate, and recognizing the generosity of deceased organ donors and their families. Additionally, it acknowledges the contributions of living organ donors, advancements in medical technology for organ transplantation, and the efforts of medical professionals to improve the process of living organ donation. SEC. 4. ORGAN DONATION PUBLIC AWARENESS PROGRAM, STUDIES AND DEMONSTRATIONS. Amends Section 377A of the Public Health Service Act to focus on public awareness, studies, and demonstrations related to organ donation. The Secretary will establish a public education program to increase awareness about organ donation and recovery rates. Grants may be provided for studies and projects to enhance organ donation, including living donation. States may receive grants for organ donor awareness and outreach programs to boost the number of organ donors. The State can receive grants for organ donation awareness and outreach programs to improve donation rates. Funds can be used for education, awareness efforts, and information dissemination. States must establish yearly benchmarks for improvement and report on the use of funds to the Secretary annually. The Secretary will support educational activities to inform healthcare professionals about organ, tissue, and eye donation, including cultural sensitivities. $5,000,000 is authorized for the Organ Donation Public Awareness Program annually from 2015 to 2019. The Secretary will allocate $5,000,000 annually from 2015 to 2019 for various purposes including studies, demonstrations, grants to States, and educational activities related to organ donation awareness.
